title: Stop the Impeachment Fishing Expedition
summary: Congress has no business investigating the president for conduct that occurred before he took office.. As William Barr begins his term as attorney general, House Democrats are aiming a "subpoena cannon" at President Trump, hoping to disable his presidency with investigations and possibly gather evidence to impeach him. Mr. Trump fired back in his State of the Union address: "If there is going to be peace and legislation, there cannot be war and investigation." To protect the presidency and separation of powers, Mr. Barr should be prepared to seek a stay of all congressional investigations of Mr. Trump's prepresidential conduct.

title: We're Suing the SEC to Protect the Stock Market
summary: An ill-advised price-control program would reduce transparency and increase volatility.. The S&P 500 swung up and down more than 1% on nine different days in December, a gyrating month dominated by uncertainty over the Federal Reserve and a looming government shutdown. On Dec. 18, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin met with reporters to assess the damage. "In my opinion," he said, "market structure has led to a lot more volatility." And it wasn't yet Christmas Eve when the Dow Jones Industrial Average plunged another 653 points.

title: Saving Europe by Destroying It From Within
summary: Euroskeptics may bolster the bloc by shifting focus away from institutions and onto the needs of people.. Brussels anticipates European Parliament elections in May with a growing sense of dread. Anti-European Union parties could capture one-third of the seats in the pan-Continental legislature, positioning them to block most important EU projects.

title: Identity Politics Promote Diversity Delusions
summary: Despite good intentions, the school's racial diversity goal was thwarted, parents were disappointed and no student was well served.. Regarding Heather Mac Donald's "Diversity Delusions at North Carolina" (op-ed, Feb. 11): A simplified example of the direct counterproductive outcomes of lowered admissions standards for minority STEM applicants was clearly on display at my daughters' small, rural Virginia middle school in the 1990s.

title: Insurers' Lobby Puts Drug Price Blame on Pharma
summary: Casting blame for high drug prices on insurance providers, pharmacy-benefit managers or others is the definition of fake news.. Regarding Adam J. Fein's "Don't Blame Drug Prices on 'Big Pharma'" (op-ed, Feb. 4): Americans should pay less for their medications. The problem is the prices drugmakers set. And the consequences hurt consumers, patients and hardworking taxpayers.

title: Why Physical Therapy for Pain Can Be an Alternative to Opioids
summary: The CDC stresses physical therapy is especially effective at reducing pain and improving function in cases of low back pain, fibromyalgia and hip and knee osteoarthritis.. Missing from the article "A New Prognosis for Pain Care" (Journal Report, Feb. 7) is the valuable role of physical therapy. The opioid crisis in the U.S. makes it clear pain-management strategies have to change. Rather than masking pain through the use of prescription drugs, we need to treat the underlying cause through proven treatments like physical therapy.

title: Progressive Democrats Claim Victory as Amazon Scraps New York Plans
summary: Decision deals a blow to Gov. Cuomo and Mayor de Blasio, who came together in a rare show of unity to offer billions in incentives to get company to place a headquarters in Queens. Progressive Democrats, who had objected to New York's willingness to promise Amazon.com Inc. billions of dollars in incentives, claimed victory in the company's decision to drop plans for a headquarters there.

title: ACLU Defends Its Anti-BDS Law Policy, Cites First Amendment Rights
summary: This has nothing to do with discrimination against people and everything to do with Americans' First Amendment right to boycott.. Prof. Eugene Kontorovich accuses the American Civil Liberties Union of hypocrisy because we challenge "anti-BDS" laws that prohibit contractors from boycotting Israel while we defend antidiscrimination laws that require businesses to serve the public ("For the ACLU, Antipathy to Israel Trumps Antidiscrimination," op-ed, Feb. 12). In fact, our position is based soundly on established First Amendment principles.

title: Nvidia Still Has a Lot of Decks to Clear
summary: Chip maker's rising inventory means strong recovery needed later in the year. Nvidia proved two things on Thursday afternoon: Things will get worse before they get better for the once-highflying chip maker, and dead cats really do bounce.

title: Brown-Forman CIO Looks to Data for Smarter Booze
summary: Analytics played a role in launch of new brand of rye whiskey. When Jack Daniel's maker Brown-Forman Corp. earlier this month launched a new brand of rye, it leveraged a growing prowess in data analytics to ensure the market could handle more whiskey.

title: XPO Lowers Profit Outlook, Drops Acquisition Plan for New Share Buybacks
summary: Logistics company says loss of business from a single 'large customer' will restrain growth this year. XPO Logistics Inc. lowered its profit outlook for 2019 on Thursday, citing a substantial loss of business from its largest customer, and launched its second stock buyback plan effort since December.

title: Senate Confirms Barr as Attorney General
summary: Experience includes stint as attorney general under President George H.W. Bush, top legal role for Verizon. WASHINGTON-The Senate confirmed William Barr as attorney general Thursday, putting the veteran of corporate and Washington legal circles in charge of a Justice Department that has been rocked by departures, political storms and the special counsel's Russia investigation.

title: CBS Investors' Glass Is Half Empty
summary: Despite strong streaming subscriber growth, CBS disappointed investors overall and they remain justifiably wary. CBS Corp. shares shed one-quarter of their value last year thanks to legal battles and #MeToo allegations, but they have started 2019 on a bright note.

title: Icahn to Push Caesars to Consider Selling Itself
summary: Billionaire shareholder activist has a stake of about 10% and wants the company to explore a sale after receiving at least two approaches. Carl Icahn is placing his chips on a sale of Caesars Entertainment Corp.

title: Deadly Bombing Targets Indian Security Personnel in Kashmir
summary: Pakistani militant group Jaish e-Mohammad claims responsibility for attack on convoy in troubled region, sparking calls for retaliation. A bombing attack claimed by a Pakistan-based militant group against a convoy carrying Indian security personnel killed dozens in the troubled region of Kashmir.

title: Dollar Falls After Disappointing Retail Sales Report
summary: The largest monthly drop in retail sales since 2009 raises fears about U.S. economic growth. The dollar fell Thursday after a report that U.S. retail sales fell significantly in December, heightening concerns about a slowdown in U.S. economic growth.

title: Amazon's Pullout From Queens, N.Y., Stuns Real-Estate Industry
summary: Developers had rushed into the Long Island City neighborhood to be near the new HQ2. Amazon.com Inc.'s announcement that it is ditching plans for a corporate headquarters in New York City stunned real-estate speculators, developers and renters who had rushed into the Long Island City neighborhood to be near the new HQ2.

title: Coca-Cola Expects Sales Growth to Slow in 2019
summary: Beverage maker posts profit as revenue gets a lift from demand for tea, sports drinks; shares fall 8.4%. Coca-Cola Co. reported slightly stronger-than-expected revenue for its latest quarter, boosted by demand for tea, coffee, water and sports drinks, but the beverage company expects sales will slow down this year.

title: FedEx's No. 2 Executive to Leave, Weeks After Joining Board
summary: FedEx veteran David Bronczek became a director on Jan. 28 and was a leading internal candidate to succeed founder and CEO Fred Smith. FedEx Corp. said its No. 2 executive David Bronczek is leaving the company and stepping down from its board, just a few weeks after the company veteran became a director.

title: Trump Has Gained Weight Since Last Year, White House Physician Says
summary: President weighs in at 243 pounds, will be receiving increased dose of a cholesterol-lowering drug. WASHINGTON-President Trump has gained weight over the past year but remains in good health, according to details of his annual physical released Thursday by the White House.

summary: Various events mark the anniversary of deadly mass shooting at Florida high school. Mourners in Parkland, Fla., and elsewhere gathered Thursday to commemorate the first anniversary of the shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School that left 17 people dead.

summary: U.S. Mideast blueprint to be divulged after Israeli elections in April. title: Pence Accuses Europe of Busting Sanctions Against 'Murderous' Iran
summary: U.S. vice president, speaking in Warsaw, takes France, Britain and Germany to task for trade vehicle. summary: Key moments in the company's decision to pick-and then drop-the Big Apple.

title: Retail Sales Fell in December at Fastest Pace Since 2009
summary: The government report sent stocks lower and raised new questions about the vigor of economic growth. WASHINGTON-U.S. retailers registered a far worse December selling season than many analysts had realized, according to a government report Thursday that sent stocks lower and raised new questions about the vigor of economic growth.

title: Will Republicans Start Winning on Health Care?
summary: Medical inflation is low and Democratic ideas are scaring voters.. Prices of health care products and services have been rising very slowly in the Trump era. Meanwhile the President's opponents are embracing increasingly radical plans for the sector. The issue that enabled Democrats to take the House in 2018 may present a challenge for the party in 2020.

title: Debt Investors Embrace 'Upside Down' World After Fed Shift
summary: Signs that the Federal Reserve may be done with its yearslong campaign to raise interest rates are sending ripples through fixed-income markets. Signs that the Federal Reserve may be done with its yearslong campaign to raise interest rates are sending ripples through fixed-income markets, holding down interest rates for a wide swath of borrowers.

title: New CFO at Videogame Tech Startup Unity Brings Tech Savvy
summary: Kim Jabal helped helped orchestrate the sale of Weebly to financial-technology company Square. Unity Technologies, a closely watched startup valued at an estimated $3.2 billion, named a new chief financial officer with extensive experience in the fast-growing tech sector.

summary: The strategy would conclude an effort to drain stimulus from the financial system earlier than officials once anticipated. Federal Reserve officials are zeroing in on a strategy to end the wind-down of their $4 trillion asset portfolio as soon as this year, which would conclude an effort to drain stimulus from the financial system earlier than they had once anticipated.

title: First 2 Primary Debates Could Have Up to 20 Presidential Contenders
summary: Candidates will need to achieve at least 1% in a set of polls, show ability to raise funds online. WASHINGTON-As many as 20 Democratic presidential contenders could qualify for the first two televised primary debates beginning in June, the party announced Thursday.

title: Vimeo Chases Video Producers With Its First Big Ad Campaign
summary: A video platform pursues creators' budgets instead of viewers' wallets. The video-sharing platform Vimeo Inc. is publicizing the services it offers creators, in an effort to capitalize on booming demand for video.

title: Oil Prices Rise Amid Confidence in OPEC Production Cut
summary: Rally continues for a third day as report shows imports sharply dropping. Oil prices rose on Thursday for a third straight session amid increasing evidence that Saudi Arabia and other major oil producers are making good on a pledge to reduce production.

title: Big Tech's Welcome Mat Is Fraying
summary: Amazon's New York misadventure a sign of public's growing wariness of tech's clout. Amazon.com just learned the hard way that there is a price to pay for being on top. Its Big Tech peers are likely to share some of the bill.

title: Congress Mulls Curbing Presidential Trade Authority
summary: Two proposals would increase oversight of White House trade actions under decades-old national-security provision. WASHINGTON-Appetite is growing in Congress to claw back authority from the executive branch and play a greater role in U.S. trade policy, just as the Trump administration resumes trade talks with China on Thursday.

title: Six Flags Shares Fall as Company Delays New Parks in China
summary: Stock price is down nearly 19% in the past 12 months.. Six Flags Entertainment Corp. said it would delay opening new theme parks in China as the country's economy slows, resulting in lower-than-expected revenue in its latest quarter.

title: 'Birds of Passage': Splendor and the Grass
summary: Colombia's entry in this year's Oscars is a story of the Wayúu indigenous people, globalization and the drug trade.. 'Birds of Passage" begins, appropriately enough, with a bird dance. The bird is a young woman, Zaida (Natalia Reyes), her flaming red shawl billowing forth to become her wings. Her dance, the yonna, is a gorgeous mating ritual practiced by the Wayúu indigenous people of Colombia, where the action plays out in the 1970s and 1980s. And the mate she chooses, Rapayet (José Acosta), proves to be a budding entrepreneur who must balance tribal and family traditions against an explosion of prosperity that he helps create by supplying marijuana for consumption in North America. The film can be harrowing in its repetitive violence, but never less than fascinating as a piece of ethnology, with magic-realist dimensions, that amounts to an origin story of the Latin American drug trade.

title: The Rolls-Royce of Multi-Cookers
summary: This cast-iron cooker from Japan offers ease, versatility, stove-to-table appeal and serious heat. WE CAN OFFICIALLY stop debating which is better: the heat-conducting prowess of a Dutch oven or the touch-of-a-button convenience of a multi-cooker. Have it both ways with the Musui-Kamado, from the Japanese company Vermicular. The ingenious design sets an enameled cast-iron pot on an induction-heating base. The lid seals in moisture for remarkably succulent roast chicken-or how about sweet potatoes "steam roasted" with a mere spoonful of water? Radiant heat and precise temperature control make the process foolproof, whether you're braising, baking, steaming or even sous-vide-ing. $670 for the set, $300 for the pot alone, vermicular.us

title: 'Alita: Battle Angel' Review: Big Eyes, Throbbing Heart, Muddled Mind
summary: Robert Rodriguez's film about a fighting cyborg with an invincible body develops weakness in the head.. She's a slip of a girl with huge Keane eyes in a face shaped like an inverted teardrop. When she puts an urgent question to a boy she really cares about, you hope he comes up with the right answer. "Does it bother you that I'm not completely human?" she asks shyly. "You are the most human person I have ever met," he replies, suggesting that love may not always be blind but it can suffer from selective sight.

title: Dow Closes Lower After Disappointing Retail Sales
summary: Retail sales in December declined at the fastest pace since 2009. U.S. stocks wavered Thursday as disappointing retail sales in the crucial holiday period and mixed corporate earnings revived concerns over a slowdown in global growth.

title: World's Tax Collectors Look to Divvy Up Tech Giants' Billions
summary: Nations to wrangle over where to assess profits of Facebook, Google and others. The world's tax collectors have been gunning for Silicon Valley. Now they're trying to figure out how to divide up the spoils.

summary: Jason Van Dyke had been transferred from Illinois to a federal facility in Connecticut, state says. A former Chicago police officer convicted of killing Laquan McDonald in 2014 was attacked by inmates shortly after being transferred to a federal prison facility in Connecticut.

summary: Yield on 10-year note slides, snapping three-session streak of increases. U.S. government bond prices rose Thursday after the Commerce Department said retail sales declined in December at the fastest pace since 2009.

title: Daimler's New CFO to Face Compressed Margins, Slowing Sales
summary: Harald Wilhelm is set join Daimler as it plans to change its organizational structure. Daimler AG's incoming finance chief will face compressed profit margins, slowing sales and planned changes to the structure of the German car maker.

title: The Expert's Guide to Scoring Décor Deals Online
summary: Essential tips from e-commerce veteran and interior designer Christiane Lemieux, including the best ways to buy-and sell-vintage furniture online. HOW MANY PEOPLE do you know who have scored an authentic Sputnik lamp on eBay for $30? Exactly. When Christiane Lemieux sold her interior-design retail brand DwellStudio to Wayfair-now the largest e-commerce destination for home furnishings and décor-in 2013, she stayed on as executive creative director. Thanks to Wayfair, which she refers to as the "university of e-commerce," she soon acquired PhD-level authority in digital decorating and shopping. Ms. Lemieux's strategy for her Sputnik killing: "It was knowing exactly what I wanted, putting in as many search terms as possible and sifting through."

title: Dish Blackout, Gizmodo Unit Weigh on Univision's Results
summary: Spanish-language broadcaster posts quarterly loss amid charge at English-language web unit. Univision Communications Inc. swung to a loss in the fourth quarter, hurt by a large impairment charge on its English-language digital unit and a carriage dispute with Dish Network Corp. that negatively affected the Spanish-language broadcaster's revenue.

title: 'Lorena' Review: Cutting to the Heart of the Matter
summary: Amazon's four-part documentary about the infamous Lorena and John Wayne Bobbitt saga is a complex story that works on many levels: as social history, cultural autopsy, biography and media critique.. 'Lorena," which arrives in four parts and just in time, will be greeted by many with a disgusted shake of the head: Why devote so much valuable TV real estate to the erstwhile Mrs. Bobbitt, whose Clinton-era notoriety is based on one tiny bit of do-it-yourself surgery and a bygone tabloid tsunami? Women will smile; men will flinch. But isn't it really old news?

title: How to Decode a Wordy Wine Label
summary: What does 'Hand Selected Lots' mean, anyway? Our wine columnist takes on some of the more trying terminology and calls for clarity in labeling. SOME WORDS ON WINE labels, such as "Chardonnay" or "Sonoma," have real meaning and convey specific and genuinely useful information. Others, such as "Private Reserve" or "Hand Selected Lots," do not. In fact, in the U.S., to label a wine as "Private Reserve" or assert that it's produced from selected lots, a winemaker-or marketer-is required by law to do nothing more than say that it is.

title: Booker's Candidacy Leaves N.J. Residents Lukewarm
summary: But Democratic candidate's popularity beats that of former Gov. Christie during failed 2016 campaign. New Jersey residents aren't entirely sold on Sen. Cory Booker's run for the White House, but he's in a better position in his home state than the one in which former Gov. Chris Christie found himself during his unsuccessful 2016 bid, according to a poll released Thursday.

Ilhan Omar, who said in tweets this week that the lobbying group holds financial sway over Congress.

Officials at the world's biggest hubs scrambled to upgrade facilities to accommodate the behemoth.

Ant Financial Services Group, the world's most valuable financial-technology startup, is acquiring U.K.-based money-transfer company WorldFirst for more than £500 million (around $640 million), according to a person familiar with the matter.

title: Administrator Sells Brands of Defunct U.K. Coffee Chain Patisserie Holdings

title: This Common Flu Virus Is a Growing Threat
summary: H1N1 tends to take less of a toll on older people, but it isn't benign. The current flu season is relatively mild, at least in comparison with last year's punishing epidemic. title: Behind the Teachers Strikes
summary: In Denver as elsewhere, the union wants less accountability.. Protest signs hoisted by more than 2,600 Denver teachers would have you think this week's school strike was "for the kids" or simply about higher wages. But the standoffs in Denver and elsewhere in recent months are also about something else: unions rejecting accountability for student performance.

title: Young Children Make Good Scientists
summary: Even 4-year-olds are able to use evidence to change their beliefs about how the world works. We all know that it's hard to get people to change their minds, even when they should. Studies show that when people see evidence that goes against their deeply ingrained beliefs, they often just dig in more firmly: Climate change deniers and anti-vaxxers are good examples. But why? Are we just naturally resistant to new facts? Or are our rational abilities distorted by biases and prejudices?

title: The Beach in December: Bargain Rents in Chilly Weather
summary: Vacationers are heading to places like the Hamptons and Cape Cod in the winter to escape the crowds-and save a lot of money.. Trade in your flip flops for snowboots: Beach rentals aren't just for the summer anymore.

summary: Democratic presidential field is filled with hard-to-pronounce first and last names; 'Is it COMMA-la, or KUH-ma-la?'. summary: Insurance giant's results once again spoiled by an increase in reserves. AIG has suffered another setback in its long effort to restore trust with investors.

title: Remote Nevada Ranch, Once Bing Crosby's Hideaway, Up for Sale

In the 1940s, Bing Crosby helped put the small city of Elko, Nev., on the map when he made it his family's refuge from Hollywood. Now, one of the singer and actor's former ranches is on the market for $7.28 million.

title: How Your 401(k) Could Imitate Netflix
summary: A growing number of financial firms are launching personalized versions of target-date funds. The 401(k) is moving beyond one-size-fits-all investments.

title: How to Master the French-Girl Cat Eye
summary: The black-rimmed makeup style, as epitomized by Brigitte Bardot, is hotter than ever. But can you emulate it? A tutorial. FEW MAKEUP LOOKS are as enduring, or as tricky to perfect, as the cat eye-that upturned bit of liner that extends past one's peepers. The coquettish effect is ubiquitous, from runways (see Marni, Chanel) to the red carpet (Cardi B, Lady Gaga and Miley Cyrus all embraced the cat eye at the 2019 Grammys on Feb. 10). But no one has worn it quite like Brigitte Bardot, who was seldom photographed without her dark winged eyeliner after she broke out in the 1956 film, "And God Created Woman." "She was a little bit of a feline," said Peter Philips, the makeup maestro and creative and image director for Dior Makeup. "She wore it in a natural way." Her inimitable lids became so iconic that in 1961, French cosmetics brand Aziza made her its eye-product poster girl, running ads with the slogan: "For Bardot and for you."

title: Fed's Brainard Says Balance-Sheet Runoff Should Probably End This Year
summary: The process of passively shrinking the Fed's $4 trillion holdings of bonds and other assets 'has really done the work that it was supposed to do'. Federal Reserve governor Lael Brainard said she expected the central bank could end the runoff of its asset portfolio later this year.

title: Sarah Jessica Parker, Liv Tyler and More: A Power Block in Greenwich Village
summary: Homes along West 11th Street are owned by prominent figures including SoftBank's Marcelo Claure.. For decades New York's Greenwich Village was the center of American bohemian culture-a gathering place for artists, leftist intellectuals and eccentrics. Today it has been colonized by a different demographic: celebrities and business titans.

title: A Few Rules for a World of Tipping Just About Everyone
summary: If an airplane cabin crew gets tips, who doesn't? The IRS? Doctors?. Americans are justifiably confused about whom they are expected to tip. For years they tipped waitresses, bartenders, sanitation workers and postmen, but then plumbers, roofers, pool boys, feng shui consultants and personal trainers got into the act. Americans have learned the hard way that if you don't tip the sheet-rock guy, he'll never come back to finish the job.

title: Vacation Homes That Feel Like Summer Camp
summary: With canoeing, archery, fishing, hiking and more, these exclusive residential developments in the Blue Ridge Mountains will have wealthy homeowners singing 'Kumbaya' by the campfire.. When Marc Walters and 15 of his closest friends converge on Cashiers, N.C., in June, a spirited competition awaits. Eight, two-man teams will compete in 10 events, including Frisbee golf, shuffleboard, darts, croquet, pickleball, ping pong, pool and cornhole. Mr. Walters, a 48-year-old financial planner from Tampa, Fla., is organizing the competition, one he dubbed the Tournament of Champions, complete with a trophy. A more apt characterization, however, is this: Summer Camp for Grown-ups.

summary: A look at homes in three gated communities on the Cashiers-Highlands plateau in North Carolina. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Sweden Recalls Ambassador to China in Twist in Bookseller's Detention
summary: Daughter of detained Swedish bookseller alleges ambassador arranged meeting where Chinese businessmen demanded media silence in exchange for father's release. BEIJING-Sweden has recalled its ambassador to China and opened an internal investigation into her role in arranging a meeting where Chinese businessmen allegedly threatened the daughter of a detained Swedish bookseller, Sweden's Foreign Ministry said Thursday.

title: The Experiment That Made Einstein Famous
summary: One hundred years ago, an extraordinary feat of astronomy proved that the theory of relativity was true. One hundred years ago, at the beginning of 1919, few people outside Germany had ever heard of Albert Einstein. By the year's end, however, he had become a world-wide celebrity and a symbol of human genius. What made Einstein's reputation was one of the most important experiments in 20th-century science: a challenging, incredibly precise observation of a solar eclipse that proved his general theory of relativity for the first time.

title: Uzbekistan Makes International Bond Debut Amid Emerging Market Rally
summary: The isolated country has embarked on a set of market-friendly reforms since the death of longtime ruler Islam Karimov. In a sign that 2019's global market recovery has opened possibilities for previously untapped corners of the world, Uzbekistan made its international bond market debut Thursday with an oversubscribed $1 billion offering.

title: Coping With Annoying Travel Delays
summary: A behavioral economist answers questions on late flights, societal biases and bad drivers. Hi Dan,

title: Finally: A Men's Leather Jacket That Doesn't Convey 'Midlife Crisis'
summary: This inky green leather Hermès topper-while admittedly a splurge-will telegraph uniqueness for decades to come. LEATHER JACKETS bring to mind noise-polluting motorcycles-blame Marlon Brando and the Hells Angels for that-but Hermès, the 182-year-old French label, has crafted a leather jacket that connotes a quainter form of transportation: the horse. "This jacket is made of Étrivière lambskin, an Hermès heritage leather, originally used for horse-harness straps," explained Véronique Nichanian, the label's men's artistic director. Equestrian leather is not a startling choice for a brand that began in 1837 as a saddlery and whose logo still depicts a horse-drawn carriage. Little else about this coat is predictable, however.

title: Pope and Trusted U.S. Cardinal Clash Over Sex-Abuse Crisis
summary: Resume Subscription. VATICAN CITY-Cardinal Sean O'Malley of Boston, chief adviser to Pope Francis on protecting children from sexual abuse, called a meeting with top papal aides in 2017, concerned the Vatican wasn't living up to its promise of "zero tolerance."

title: College Basketball Turns to New Ranking System
summary: The NCAA's new-look ranking system aims to bring the March Madness selection process into the modern age. If you follow college basketball only casually until the NCAA tournament begins, there's a good chance that the only thing you know about the 2018-19 season is the existence of a very large Duke freshman named Zion. But with the regular season winding down, fans are starting to wonder whether their teams will attract an invitation to March Madness.

title: The Broken-Hearted Move Back Home
summary: The No. 1 reason adults ages 26 to 40 move back in with their parents: a romance on the rocks, according to a survey by real-estate website Homes.com.. Here's a little Valentine's Day rhyme: Good love gone bad means moving in with mom and dad.

title: Stocks to Watch: Coca-Cola, Fossil, Cisco Systems, AIG, Yelp, MGM Resorts International, Sleep Number
summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Thursday's session. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Thursday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: EPA's Top Leaders Stymied Research Unit, Report Finds
summary: Government watchdog's draft report says agency officials sidelined studies on chemicals' health risks. An Environmental Protection Agency research unit tasked with evaluating chemicals' health risks has had its work hindered by the agency's top leadership, according to a government watchdog.

title: Credit Suisse Has Rich People's Problems in Markets
summary: The Swiss bank's trading divisions look like a costly support to its main focus on wealth. The end of restructuring normally sets the stage for chief executives to proclaim glories to come. At Credit Suisse , the promise of a bright future is tainted by its still struggling equity and bond trading operations.

title: Fashion Week Set Design: Three Top Designers Reveal Their Inspiration
summary: Thanks to talents like Nian Fish, Stefan Beckman and Alexandre de Betak, the best runway shows become performance art. Here, they tell us about their favorite things. Months of work culminating in less than 10 minutes of performance: The fleeting quality of runway shows is what motivates NYC-based Nian Fish, 68, who has created presentations for designers like Calvin Klein, Tom Ford, Thom Browne, Victoria Beckham and Tory Burch, over a career that has included an 18-year stint at PR and events firm KCD. "I have a philosophy of impermanence in life, which comes from my Buddhist practice," Fish explains. Born in Kobe, Japan, to a Chinese-Japanese mother and an American father, Fish lived all over the world as a child, eventually settling in New York. After majoring in English and art in college, Fish was working for stylists Paul Cavaco and Kezia Keeble in the late '70s when she got her break: styling a Richard Avedon-lensed Dior campaign. "In those days, when you were a stylist, you literally did everything," she recalls. Her role model is her mother: "She was No. 19 in the sweatshops of Chinatown, and she moved her way up to becoming quality control," Fish says. "Recently I realized, that's what I do: I'm quality control."

title: Power Struggle: Electricity Outages Hit South Africa Months Before Election
summary: The state-owned power utility has become the president's biggest political headache ahead of the May vote. JOHANNESBURG-The biggest test to the South African president's power right now: Can he keep the power on?

title: Brief Price Gaps in Stocks May Cost Investors $2 Billion a Year
summary: Government-backed study finds nearly 24% of trades may not be executed at best available prices, can be exploited by fast traders. Nearly a quarter of U.S. equity trades may not be executed at the best price available in the market, costing investors at least $2 billion a year, according to a new study funded by the U.S. government.

title: Border Barriers, Mile by Mile
summary: What has been built so far along the U.S.-Mexico border, and what is expected next. The border-security deal being voted on by lawmakers would extend by about 55 miles the barriers along the U.S.'s southern border, marking a modest expansion rather than the transformative overhaul President Trump has at times described.

title: Credit Suisse Returns to Profit but Trading Weakness Remains
summary: Swiss lender reports a weaker-than-expected performance in its trading unit. Credit Suisse Group AG swung to a profit in the fourth quarter, despite weakness in its trading business, and posted its first annual profit since 2014 following a three-year restructuring plan.

title: Gauge of Business Prices Ticked Down at Start of 2019
summary: The decline in headline business prices was driven by a drop in goods prices. WASHINGTON-A gauge of business prices fell slightly in January, signaling overall inflation pressures remain tame.

summary: Initial claims, a proxy for layoffs across the U.S., increased by 4,000. WASHINGTON-The number of Americans filing applications for new unemployment benefits rose last week.

title: AstraZeneca Turns a Corner After a Decade of Struggles
summary: U.K. drugmaker posts its strongest sales growth since 2009, and sees more growth ahead. LONDON- AstraZeneca PLC, battered by a string of patent expiries in recent years, reported its strongest sales growth since 2009 as efforts to replenish its pipeline and pivot toward cancer drugs started to pay off.

title: Airbus to Retire the A380, the Superjumbo That Never Took Off
summary: After billions of dollars of investment, Airbus is retiring a plane it had hoped would supplant Boeing's 747. title: Prince Philip Won't Be Charged Over Car Crash
summary: The 97-year-old husband of Queen Elizabeth II was in an accident that left two passengers injured in January. title: Airbus Shows Danger of Wanting It Bigger and Faster
summary: The demise of the superjumbo A380 is a reminder that fuel efficiency has been the main driver of aircraft demand. There is something annoying about the otherwise cool job of designing airplanes: You want to build them bigger and faster, but buyers just want boring efficiency gains.

title: Trade Friction Stymies Growth in Germany and Japan
summary: Powerhouse economies avoid recession but look set for a weak year ahead. Japan and Germany avoided slipping into recession as 2018 drew to a close, but the world's third- and fourth-largest economies seem set for a year of weak expansion amid uncertainty about the future of global trade rules and the severity of China's slowdown.

title: Canadian Oil Producers Miss U.S. Opportunity

title: U.S. Push Against Huawei Gear Hits Obstacle: Carriers Love It

title: In Need of Workers, the Midwest Recruits From Puerto Rico
summary: Resume Subscription. SIDNEY, Ohio-The Instagram pitch to job seekers in Puerto Rico was tempting. summary: Apple had withdrawn sales of the iPhone 7, 7+, 8, and 8+ in December. summary: Treasury has attributed the weaker revenue-including lower corporate and individual income-tax rates-to the tax law that took effect in January 2018. title: SEC Rejects Capital Plan by Options Clearinghouse

title: U.S. Accuses Ex-Intelligence Officer of Spying for Iran
